body.p: The following sections include useful commands and approaches to mange and administrator a growing Ceph cluster.

section.title: Block Device Commands
section.p: The rbd command enables you to create, list, inspect and remove block device images. You can also use it to clone images, create snapshots, rollback an image to a snapshot, view a snapshot, etc.
To use Ceph Block Device commands, you must have access to a running Ceph cluster.

section.title: Creating a block device name
section.p: Before adding a block device to a node, you must first create an image for it in the Ceph Storage Cluster. To create a block device image, enter:
For example, to create a 1GB image named image1 that stores information in a pool named imagelist, enter:

codeblock.codeph: rbd create image1 --size 1024 rbd create bar --size 1024 --pool imagelist

section.note: You must first create a pool before you can specify it as a source.

section.title: Listing block device images

li.p: To list block devices in the rbd pool, (where rbd is the default pool name), enter:

To list block devices in a particular pool, execute the following command:

section.title: Map a block device
section.p: Use rbd to map an image name to a kernel module. You must specify the image name, the pool name, and the user name. If it is not already loaded, rbd loads the RBD kernel module.
For example:

codeblock.codeph: sudo rbd map --pool rbd myimage --id admin

section.p: If you use cephx authentication, you must also specify a secret. It may come from a keyring or a file containing the secret.

codeblock.codeph: sudo rbd map --pool rbd myimage --id admin --keyring /path/to/keyring sudo rbd map --pool rbd myimage --id admin --keyfile /path/to/file

section.title: Show Mapped block devices
section.p: To show block device images mapped to kernel modules with the rbd command, use the showmapped option.

codeblock.codeph: rbd showmapped UNMAPPING A BLOCK DEVICE

section.p: To unmap a block device image with the rbd command, use the unmap option and the device name. (By convention, the device name is the same as the block device image name).

Inactive placement groups cannot process reads or writes because they are waiting for an OSD with the most up-to-date data to come back.
Unclean placement groups contain objects that are not replicated the desired number of times. They should be in the state of recover.

li.p: To add/remove an address to/from the blacklist, enter:
ceph osd blacklist add ADDRESS[:source_port] [TIME] ceph osd blacklist rm ADDRESS[:source_port]

section.note: When adding an address, you can specify the time (in seconds) to be blacklisted; otherwise, it will configure a default time of 1 hour. A blacklisted address is prevented from connecting to any OSD. Blacklisting is most often used to prevent a lagging metadata server from making unwanted changes to data on the OSDs.
section.p: These commands are useful for failure testing, as blacklists are normally maintained automatically, and do not need manual intervention.
